abstract.text: In this work we report on the production of charged pions, kaons, and (anti) protons in pp and Pb − Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV for 3 < p T < 20 GeV/c.
The evolution of the nuclear modification factor, R AA , with collision centrality and transverse momentum is discussed.

body_text.text: Introduction
The particle identification (PID) is an important tool to study the hot and dense matter created in relativistic heavy ion collisions.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: At intermediate p T (2)(3)(4)(5)(6)(7)(8) GeV/c) hadrons can be produced not only by fragmentation but also by quark recombination.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: It allows us to learn how the medium affects the particle composition [1].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In Section 2 we describe the analysis to measure the production of π/K/p as a function of p T (3-20 GeV/c).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The discussion of the results and conclusions are presented in Sections 3 and 4, respectively.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Identification of charged hadrons at high p T

The measurement of the yields of charged pions, kaons and (anti) protons in the range 3 < p T < 20 GeV/c is statistically performed exploiting the peculiarity of the mean energy loss, dE/dx , of particles traversing the the TPC gas [2], in the relativistic rise regime (βγ : 3.6−1000) of the Bethe-Bloch (BB) curve.
body_text.section: Identification of charged hadrons at high p T

body_text.text: The TPC response was calibrated using a clean sample of π (p) identified through the weak decay topology of K 0 S (Λ).
body_text.section: Identification of charged hadrons at high p T

body_text.text: Primary pions and electrons were tagged using the Time of Flight (TOF) detector.
body_text.section: Identification of charged hadrons at high p T

body_text.text: After parametrization of the BB curve and of the dE/dx resolution as a function of the calibrated dE/dx , the measured resolution of minimum ionizing particles were 5.6% and 7.5% for low (pp) and high (Pb − Pb 0-5%) multiplicity environment, respectively.
body_text.section: Identification of charged hadrons at high p T

body_text.text: The yields were extracted by fitting the quantity ∆ π = dE/dx − dE/dx π to a sum of four Gaussian functions (π/K/p/e) in each p T interval.
body_text.section: Identification of charged hadrons at high p T

body_text.text: The means and sigmas were constrained using the aforementioned parametrization and the p T spectra obtained via factorization, as described in [3].
body_text.section: Identification of charged hadrons at high p T

body_text.text: 1 A list of members of the ALICE Collaboration and acknowledgements can be found at the end of this issue.
body_text.section: Identification of charged hadrons at high p T

body_text.text: The main source of systematic uncertainty comes from the estimation of the parameters of the fitted functions.
body_text.section: Identification of charged hadrons at high p T

body_text.text: A range of variation for those parameters was evaluated running the analysis without exploiting the information from topological and TOF PID.
body_text.section: Identification of charged hadrons at high p T

body_text.text: The parameters were randomly varied in the estimated ranges, then the yields were extracted using the same algorithm as in data.
body_text.section: Identification of charged hadrons at high p T

body_text.text: At high p T (> 10 GeV/c) the systematic uncertainties were 5%, 10% and ∼ 30 − 40% for π, K and p, respectively.
body_text.section: Identification of charged hadrons at high p T

body_text.text: Also, we added the systematic errors from the spectra of inclusive charged particles [4].

body_text.text: For completeness the lower p T results are also displayed for Pb − Pb [5,6].
body_text.section: Identification of charged hadrons at high p T

body_text.text: At intermediate p T the ratio is enhanced, this phenomenon was first observed at RHIC [7].
body_text.section: Identification of charged hadrons at high p T

body_text.text: The maximum is located at 3 GeV/c and reaches ∼ 0.8 (∼ 0.4) for the most central (peripheral) events.
body_text.section: Identification of charged hadrons at high p T

body_text.text: For higher p T (> 8 GeV/c), the ratio is consistent with fragmentation in vacuum.
body_text.section: Identification of charged hadrons at high p T

body_text.text: Figure 2 shows a comparison with the ratio in pp collisions at √ s = 7 TeV.
body_text.section: Identification of charged hadrons at high p T

body_text.text: It is interesting that even the pp data exhibit a maximum in the same p T region as observed in Pb − Pb collisions.
body_text.section: Identification of charged hadrons at high p T

body_text.text: ALICE previously reported the nuclear modification factor (R AA ) for π and p + K [3].
body_text.section: Identification of charged hadrons at high p T

body_text.text: Now Figure 3 shows the R AA as a function of p T for pions, kaons and protons, the results are presented for 0-5% and 60-80%.
body_text.section: Identification of charged hadrons at high p T

body_text.text: For the most central events and at intermediate p T (2-8 GeV/c), R AA π < R AA p and R AA π ∼ R AA K , no significant species dependence is seen at high p T .
body_text.section: Identification of charged hadrons at high p T

body_text.text: Preprint submitted to Nuclear Physics
Results
Conclusions
At intermediate p T , we observe an enhancement of the (p +p)/(π + + π − ) ratio.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: Within systematics, π/K/p are equally suppressed at high p T which suggests that the fragmentation is not modified by the medium.
body_text.section: Conclusions
